prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G28 band3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We mosaic bia 3.1mm dust continuum including the areas of 8 starless cores and the long slit position of previous extinction law study using Spitzer-IRS.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are using full band width of continuum emission in band 3.
We choose 6arcsec of angular resolution for mosaic efficiency. The 10arcsec is the slit width of Spitzer-IRS which we used to study this IRDC before.
We calculate the desired peak flux by using the assumption given in Tan et al. (2013) PPVI review with inputs of 0.1 g cm^-2 and 10K.

We calculate the desired peak flux by using the assumption given in Tan et al. (2013) PPVI review with inputs of 0.1 g cm^-2 and 10K.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: G28 band6-3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We mosaic bia 1.3mm dust continuum including the areas of 8 starless cores and the long slit position of previous extinction law study using Spitzer-IRS.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are using full band width of continuum emission in band 6.
We choose 2.9arcsec of angular resolution for mosaic efficiency. The 10arcsec is the slit width of Spitzer-IRS which we used to study this IRDC before.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Measuring how dust opacity varies with environment in dense molecular cores is important in understanding the physical processes that evolve dust via grain growth and mantle accretion. More importantly, having a secure dust opacity model is critical to estimating core masses and mass surface density profiles where the resolution permits. The distribution of mass in star forming cores is an important input in distinguishing between different star formation theories. We propose ALMA continuum observations of one particular infrared dark cloud for which we have complementary estimates of dust opacity and mass surface density from infrared extinction studies including a novel new method using infrared spectroscopy. By comparing the ALMA inferred opacities to the infrared inferred opacities we will be more robust to the intrinsic biases of each method. ALMA is critical in providing data on the same resolution and spatial scales as the infrared (Spitzer) measurements.
